description: English grammar points organized by level

beginner.title: Present Simple - To Be
beginner.meaning: Used to describe states, facts, and identity
beginner.usage: I am, You are, He/She/It is, We are, They are

beginner.title: Articles - A, An, The
beginner.meaning: Words that define nouns as specific or unspecific
beginner.usage: 'a' before consonant sounds, 'an' before vowel sounds, 'the' for specific items
beginner.notes: Articles don't exist in many languages - practice frequently

elementary.title: Past Simple - Regular Verbs
elementary.notes: Spelling rules: double consonant (stopped), y to i (studied)

intermediate.title: Present Perfect
intermediate.meaning: Links past to present - experiences, changes, incomplete time
intermediate.usage: Use with ever, never, just, already, yet, for, since

examples.english: I have lived here for 5 years.
examples.explanation: Started in past, continues to present

examples.english: Have you ever been to Japan?
examples.explanation: Asking about experience at any time in life

intermediate.notes: Don't use with specific past times (yesterday, last week)

advanced.title: Third Conditional
advanced.pattern: If + past perfect, would have + past participle
advanced.meaning: Imaginary past situations and their hypothetical results
advanced.usage: Express regret, imagine different past outcomes

examples.english: If I had known, I would have helped.
examples.explanation: I didn't know, so I didn't help

advanced.notes: The situation is impossible to change - it's in the past

proficient.title: Inversion for Emphasis
proficient.usage: After: Never, Rarely, Seldom, Not only, Hardly, No sooner

examples.english: Never have I seen such dedication.
examples.explanation: Normal: I have never seen such dedication

proficient.notes: Very formal, often used in writing and speeches
